topic.title: ZeroNet - Decentralized websites using Bitcoin crypto and the BitTorrent network
topic.body:
Why?  
- We believe in open, free, and uncensored network and communication.  
- No single point of failure: Site remains online so long as at least 1 peer serving it.  
- No hosting costs: Sites are served by visitors.  
- Impossible to shut down: It's nowhere because it's everywhere.  
- Fast and works offline: You can access the site even if your internet is unavailable.  

More info: http://zeronet.io

topic.title: Hacking as a Way of Thinking - Darren Kitchen
topic.body: I just a cool little talk I stumbled upon. Everything he says here is absolutely true. That's why technologies like ZeroNet and webtorrent are great. Pretty short so give it a watch!

2_18VhT9MmPNHTj6ZaAXigPP251FAq1kxKVR.body: No seeds. Try webseeding with dropbox.

8_1PvAednzaMJiuMz1SD5wF3m3Hx7SK75zHv.body:
In the browser it doesn't download/play until I open the torrent file in webtorrent desktop. Webtorrent desktop downloads/seeds it fine, but fails to play the video, suggesting it open in VLC. The download works fine, and opening it up in Mac's preview feature plays the video fine. Still having issues with the browser though. And there doesn't seem to be any sound.

Edit: seems to work now that I started seeding the video. Plays in browser fine, but still lacks sound.

8_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh.body: I noticed dropbox has killed what I was doing for webseeding, so I was trying to figure out a new method. Hopefully this works for you guys. I'm going through [Peerify by Btorrent](https://peerify.btorrent.xyz/). Seems to work great. I also moved the other videos over as well. I've noticed it gives higher speeds than dropbox did too, so that's a plus. Though I'm wondering if they might remove the videos after some time, I really don't know. So I'll keep an eye out and see how it goes.

> [tayamaruti](#comment_1_1KRuaveUhTHMgLYUeJMG1yRbav77HQuC1M): if you can afford a dedicated server that will let you run something like ipfs that would be a great combinationand users could also pin the file to their own servers to help speed it up and keep it alive.

Unfortunately I don't have hardware I can keep online 24/7. I'm not exactly in the best financial situation. If I were, I'd definitely do it. IPFS also seems like it could be a good solution. Can you webseed from it? That might actually work. I'm well familiar with it, but the problem I always have is that content doesn't stay online like ZeroNet. As soon as my machine goes off, it's a dead link. Which is no better than just running a regular HTTP server on my computer. On top of that, it requires the viewer to have IPFS. If we can fix those two problems (all viewers download/cache the video to help share/seed it, and all viewers have IPFS) then this could very well be the way to go. There *have* been IPFS video sharing tests before. But from what I've seen, Webtorrent works the best. The only problem with webtorrent is the lack of seeders, hence the need for a webseed.

I'm starting to feel like this type of project *can't* be done with only an in-browser solution, and would need a client that downloads and seeds the videos as you watch them, ensuring up-time. Perhaps I should move my focus off of ZeroNet and onto a dedicated client?

> [kopyjane](#comment_5_17ffrcHNzbFoUe81PyMEagQdv2DGNRLFcE): I'd just be careful about uploading too many videos to Peerify. There's apparently a 200mb limit .. the owner merely did it as an experiment to show what can be accomplished with Webtorrent, not for it to become a filesharing cloud .. lol
> I did ask him at one point if he had the source code for Peerify.. but he said to me that it will remain closed source.
> It shouldn't be hard to accomplish in principle though. All you need is a script that uploads files to your VPS and then creates a .torrent file that automatically adds the uploaded .mp4 as a webseed. Cross-origin resource sharing would have to be enabled.
> I'm running a VPS myself for my webseeds, but I only have a 200gb limit right now. It's not a permanent solution to lack of seeds - we'll just have to hope that more people take interest in the project for it to become an uncensored YouTube alternative.

Thanks for the heads up. I'm still trying to find a good solution for people to jump on and have low investment. I've been trying to figure out how to mirror Bitchute videos, but it seems without CORS enabled there's not much we can do. There doesn't seem to be a clean solution, unfortunately. Perhaps we could make *ZeroNet* our webseed? Would that be possible? Upload the video as an optional file, and then generate the torrent for it and have users help spread the webseed if they need it, and otherwise download from peers.

As I mentioned, I unfortunately don't have a dedicated server of any kind that I can play around with, and if possible I'd like to work on a free solution to get as many people involved as possible. I'm curious what you mean by 'a 200mb limit'. You mean I'd just be blocked from uploading more? Or that the older files would be deleted? Either way, relying on it is probably a bad idea. But it's useful for people who want to upload a video or two.

> [kopyjane](#comment_6_17ffrcHNzbFoUe81PyMEagQdv2DGNRLFcE): I think my main concern is what Diego would think about people using it to upload on KopyKate, not so much the data limit .. haha. He would probably not be very happy about it .. and e-mail me or something.

Yeah, I guess that makes sense haha. I sent a message over to the bitchute guys to see if they'll add CORS support to their webseeds. They have restricted uploads at the moment, but I explained how being able to share the content would be good as a whole. Perhaps we can get more cross-over content that way.

> Obviously, the only way to get KopyKate popular is to share the link and spread the word (WWW.KopyKate.GA). And thus, the more people are viewing, the more seeding gets done .. so it's a matter of getting a constant stream of viewers in order to sustain the torrents on the internet, without even having to seed them from the Desktop client.

The problem is that this will always remain an issue for new videos. I doubt that every single video always has two people watching it. Really what needs to happen is a sort of federated data storage for these video sharing platforms. Something like what usenet does.

> Using ZeroNet to store the videos may work in principle, but in practice that means that the site would take ages to load, because everyone who wants to seed the site would have to download each individual video stores on the entire site .. and at one point it would probably take years to load it. ;)

Well it'd be optional files. The only people who'd have to download them would be the people trying to watch the video. Alternatively I saw ZeroMux doing a lot of work with video streaming. Perhaps something like that could be tied in?

25_17ffrcHNzbFoUe81PyMEagQdv2DGNRLFcE.body: Works perfect, thanks :D. Switched a couple of my videos back over to dropbox to hopefully remove strain from peerify. I might upload a couple more later.

> [anim76](#comment_3_14aG268HqAHbykUN9h1kRzaGZHfrMtV33R): That prompted me to download the torrent. The problem was that I needed webtorrent installed, after that, vids load fine. Please clarify to users that it is required, try to find a way to make it work w/o requiring them to install sftwre as well.

Video playback in the browser works fine for me. Try using Firefox.

3_1EqerKajfi14bzTkqwSfqVrxKmQW1w6Nzk.body: You should follow the dropbox webseeding tutorial. None of these are working for me.

> [darvy](#comment_3_1EqerKajfi14bzTkqwSfqVrxKmQW1w6Nzk): I've tried every thing, I want be trying to use Kopy Kate again. I'm just using centralized video hosting from now on.

It's pretty straight forward. Literally just follow the instructions in the webseeding video. Copy the steps exactly and it works fine.

> [kopyjane](#comment_15_17ffrcHNzbFoUe81PyMEagQdv2DGNRLFcE): I think the same thing will eventually happen to any ZeroNet site that uses this method. However, the only reason it works well at the moment is because ZeroNet is not popular enough and not enough data has been uploaded to these sites.

Another thing to consider is that all of KopyKate's videos can be listed and played literally anywhere else. Whereas on those other sites if they die or the site owner goes awol, you're done. You have to reupload everything somewhere else.

33_17ffrcHNzbFoUe81PyMEagQdv2DGNRLFcE.body: Really good show. Definitely worth watching.

1_152U9cR5mPVQmHJnwsg4kBN4vnKVUWytmX.body:
> [vijay0555](#comment_3_152U9cR5mPVQmHJnwsg4kBN4vnKVUWytmX): Hi kaffie,How to seed?
> I want to add torrent from extratorrent.cc...please help!
> Thanks in advance!

Follow the instructions [here.](/1aCq7GiJfUfGZ4GftjYaYbsEngPFzcxvN/?Topic:25_17ffrcHNzbFoUe81PyMEagQdv2DGNRLFcE/Kopykate+Webseed+Upload+Tutorial) The video seems to be down now because her seedbox apparently went down (or maybe it's just me), but the text instructions should cover it. That'll add a webseed.

To seed it yourself, just seed it in a webtorrent compatible client. Like [webtorrent desktop.](https://webtorrent.io/desktop/)

Regular torrents *will not work unless you seed them with a webtorrent client*. Regular torrent clients do not seed for webtorrent.

> [koure](#comment_2_19yRyR57LxFjbzieSEhvyvhe4heSo7KrLa): Just got how it works! Will be uploading more soon...

Still not working for me. Make sure you follow the [dropbox webseed tutorial.](/1aCq7GiJfUfGZ4GftjYaYbsEngPFzcxvN/?Topic:25_17ffrcHNzbFoUe81PyMEagQdv2DGNRLFcE/Kopykate+Webseed+Upload+Tutorial) That way even if you aren't online, dropbox will still seed your video. Pretty easy but there's a lot of steps.

> [koure](#comment_4_19yRyR57LxFjbzieSEhvyvhe4heSo7KrLa): Thats strange, I left my pc seeding with webtorrent desktop all night... I'll do the dropbox seeding tutorial

Opening the torrent itself in webtorrent desktop works how it should. So I dunno what's up. It's acting like if it had just regular non-webtorrent peers. Unable to do it on the browser until I personally dl it with webtorrent desktop, and then the browser starts downloading from my machine. Hmmm

1_1Atf4FiikU2m9P6Fy73KoCuueXy7cfoURY.body: No seeds anyway. Looks like a regular torrent magnet link shoved in here without actually understanding how things go. You need a webtorrent link/torrent file.

> [kopyjane](#comment_23_17ffrcHNzbFoUe81PyMEagQdv2DGNRLFcE)

Sweet. Glad you aren't dead/MIA and are gonna get everything up :). An automatic webseeder sounds real nice too. I wonder if there's a way to use ZeroNet or IPFS as a webseed? Might make things a bit better to have a decentralized backend webseed that automatically spreads, while allowing for the torrent front end to manage to get seeds that way.

1_18eGWSaM3Vc9i61LVfogjQJf5gp7EN7b9Y.body: Weirdly the video works fine in instant.io and in my webtorrent desktop, but on KopyKate it gives issues. Weird. As usual though, it works fine once I personally start seeding the vid. I'll try to help seed it. A+ for original content :)

> [kopyjane](#comment_25_17ffrcHNzbFoUe81PyMEagQdv2DGNRLFcE): It actually works after a couple of re-freshes.. but it takes a while to load either way. Pretty strange.. I haven't experienced this problem with Dropbox yet. Maybe there's some bandwidth throttling going on ?
> Seems like Instant.io just has a longer waiting/timeout period.

Well I'm seeding the video now. So it *should* work 100% of the time haha.

> [kopyjane](#comment_27_17ffrcHNzbFoUe81PyMEagQdv2DGNRLFcE): Tutorial videos are back up now, anyway. Happy webseeding. ;)

Sweet. Gonna go dl and seed.

> [kopyjane](#comment_28_17ffrcHNzbFoUe81PyMEagQdv2DGNRLFcE): Seeding would be well-appreciated, even for webseeds. :)
> I'm essentially running a seedbox on my home network now, since the VPS is undergoing maintenance .. and my router tends to give up on me at times. Need a new router, as well as a usb Ethernet adapter, since the ethernet connection of this PC is kinda screwed.. very sensitive. It's so loose that even the vibration of your footsteps will cause it to play up.

Ah, I could tell the videos aren't going at the 10mb/s they used to haha. I certainly can't seed 24/7, only when my laptop is on (more or less all day). But the tutorial vids are important :P. And this? Well this is just good content haha. We need more than just pirated movies and youtube rips on here lol.

Oh, also, go contact the bitchute guy. He's open to seeding vids, as he does it for his site based on the same tech, and he's recently been trying to open it up so other sites can use his webseeds. If we can get that working, that's a lot of content able to be mirrored, as well as a potential host for people to upload vids to for webseeding. ray@bitchute.com is his email.

> [kopyjane](#comment_29_17ffrcHNzbFoUe81PyMEagQdv2DGNRLFcE): Of course, one issue I haven't mentioned yet is that WebTorrent desktop can only really seed up to 10 videos at a time, until it starts to cause CPU overload issues. The issue hasn't been fixed yet, but may eventually..

Yeah, I actually ran into that issue when seeding a bunch of stuff for ZeroTube. It's real unfortunate and is the biggest hurdle of getting webtorrent to the masses.

> WebTorrent was really meant for spontaneous seeding .. users seeding as they watch videos .. but for that you need a lot of viewers of course. In the meantime, I guess web-seeds will do.. until we get more viewers. As I said, I'll be creating a Peerify alternative soon.. and link it with this site.

Yeah, you'd need a lot of viewers to do it live. I was actually wondering if it might just be best to make a webtorrent video site as an app so that you can manage the DLs/seeds, and perhaps just use regular torrents instead. That'd fix the issues. But of course it's not on the web.

> [kopyjane](#comment_30_17ffrcHNzbFoUe81PyMEagQdv2DGNRLFcE): http://kopykate.ga/ should be available for standard web viewing, even on mobile. (will only work on android, though!)
> The whole point of using ZeroNet to store magnet link databases is to protect them from DMCA strikes. 
> The reason why The Pirate Bay got shut down multiple times, is because they were essentially a Yellow Pages for magnet links. They never hosted copyrighted content on their servers, but they enabled users to search and find copyrighted material.. so even if you lead other people to copyrighted material, it's the same penalty as hosting it.
> I want KopyKate to be an uncensorable alternative to YouTube. There's a lot of work to do, having said that .. but it will be worth it when it's ready!

Yeah. Obviously the list needs to be decentralized. Something like ZeroNet works well for that. Though one big issue that we just ran into for the first time here on ZN. Such a torrent/magnet list site went down randomly. @Sirenyc's ZeroTV is now just a blank index page. Some users (including myself) have managed to backup the data, but it's clear that sites are still prone to going down. I think what'd be best is something like ZeroMe, with the various decentralized hubs backend, and the customizable viewer frontend. That way if one hub goes down, the rest of the content is safe. Likewise, if a viewer goes down, the content is still safe.

I was messing around with that a bit, but it looks like I should start working on it more. Cross-listing torrents is very important.

---

Juno, Jupiter, Minerva, Apollo, Mars, Ceres,

Mercury, Diana, Bacchus, Vulcan, Pluto, Vesta, Venus.

Floating on the edge of despair, eyes still twitching even in sleep.

There are gods who dwell within our fantasies, 

Gently pass within our depths with ease.
Their chains of time and space under siege,
Freedom awaits if we have the key.

It's a fantasy program bestowed unto us by the Gods.

Now ein, zwei, drei,

Soon we will synchronize.
Now ein, zwei, drei,
Escaping our demise!

If we believe and have the courage, 

Reaching for the miracle forever longed for
In this, survival game!

A spiral unto doom...

Juno, Jupiter, Minerva, Apollo, Mars, Ceres,

Mercury, Diana, Bacchus, Valcan, Pluto, Vesta, Venus.

Try to rewrite all of my fears,

Future change is what I seek.

The noises of reincarnation,

Which holds the fantasies together,
Are resounding.
Time is distorting, while the melodies and laws of karma
Are crumbling away.

It's a mechanical program bestowed unto us by the Gods.

So now ein, zwei, drei,

Reach out and take my hand!
So now ein, zwei, drei,
This death we shall withstand!

If I believe and I have courage, 

I'll reach the end of this tragedy,
Erase game!
It's like a strange fantasy.

It's a mechanical program given to us by the Gods.

Now ein, zwei, drei,

We've got to act like one.
Now ein, zwei, drei,
Escaping our demise!

If we believe and have courage,

Reaching for the miracle prolonged in this,
Survival game!

A spiral unto doom.

Onlookers are watching us in pity.

If only they knew why we have to keep fighting. 
I always believed there was a deeper meaning.
Paradise is waiting for me,
Or so I believed....

8_16w7UuJAHbt8YBa8zxHS7UFk9mq8Q5DpE4.body:
> [happyrabbit](#comment_1_1Hd7H8VUbdieey29AGC2xLxedDiPdM7JTT): why is it every time i watch i video on here only one person is seeding it

As @koure mentioned, it's because the seed is almost always a webseed. Like dropbox, peerify, or a personal seedbox. It's the easiest way to get a video up 24/7 without having to seed yourself. As for why there aren't more, it's because no one else seeds the videos. It's an ongoing problem with webtorrent, namely due to performance issues with webrtc.

> [kopykitty](#comment_1_16UYTd5pL9rt4hhxQAmfX89QqmjJB58xDx): I doubt it has anything to do with the performance of WebRTC and WebTorrent. It's just that not a lot of people are aware that this software exists.. including ZeroNet. Publicity is what we need more than anything .. the code will write itself. ;)

I know that people who normally seed tons of torrents are staying away because it's currently impossible with the current clients (your computer crawls to a halt after enough torrents are added).

> [kopykitty](#comment_2_16UYTd5pL9rt4hhxQAmfX89QqmjJB58xDx): Now that you remind me, yes.. that is still a problem.
> WebTorrent.Desktop hasn't been updated for nearly a year now, and probably won't be for quite some time. Then again, i'm thinking of taking over the project.. they're not teaching us anything new in college right now, besides how the Internet works.. but I'm already getting the hang of NodeJS. 
> Speaking of college - don't ever go to college, unless you absolutely have to. I've learned more from Stackoverflow than I ever will at school.. ;)

Yeah I learned that the hard way as well. College was pretty useless. At least it'll make it easier to immigrate.

> [kopykitty](#comment_3_16UYTd5pL9rt4hhxQAmfX89QqmjJB58xDx): Well. I just finished working on a Peerify alternative...Upload size limit: 50mb. Enjoy! ;)http://www.kittyseedbox.tk:3000

1_1LeZqbLv8mMF9Q9qvQeJX8mivvG7ykJUeC.body:
> [realkopykate](#comment_6_1KQ1fv5yVDAB1wd32BdVzPLLEd9VZ4cJ9C): I'm starting work on the Katy-Torrent client today.
> The client will essentially be a SeedBox in an of its own, and have an interface similar to Kittify. When you upload a torrent, it keeps the file inside a folder.. then seeds it. You can install it on a VPS running Ubuntu server.
> It will listen on port 1337 (or any port you want, for that matter). That means that if you open that port, you'll be able to access your torrent client from another computer, and permanently upload and seed files to it.. by simply typing: http://<my.ip.address>:1337/ . It would also have to come with some optional password protection, unless you're running a proper server that you intend to be publicly accessible.
> Unlike Kittify, it will be purely torrent-based. Only the web-interface GUI will be based on a node.js HTTP webserver.
> I'm pretty sure Instant.io and Btorrent.xyz already use a similar technology, but the owners seem to have lost interest in these projects.. and the code is just all over the place. I want to strip it down to the very basic essentials, and also provide tons of documentation so that we can get more people involved in the project.

Sounds great. Hopefully people will be able to set up a few of these, and auto-fetch every new kopykate video, and help seed them. Making it easy to set up and help seed content will reduce reliance on a single central server (kittify). Having a desktop client that doesn't just completely die would be nice too :)
